title: Telephone Contact Billing
scenario: A CSS provider has a 12-minute phone call with an enrollee to check on their housing stability. The enrollee was distressed and needed support. Can the provider bill for this service?
question: Is this telephone contact billable?
options: Yes, all phone calls with enrollees are billable
No, the call must be at least 15 minutes to be billable
Yes, but only if it's video call
No, phone calls are never billable
explanation: According to page 12, telephone calls of at least 15 minutes are billable. Since this call was only 12 minutes, it cannot be billed.

title: Age-Based Eligibility
scenario: A 15-year-old youth who has been chronically homeless for the past year is referred for Supportive Housing services. They meet all other eligibility criteria including mental health needs.
question: Can this youth be enrolled in CSS?
options: Yes, age exceptions can be made for homeless youth
No, they must be at least 16 years old
Yes, if they have parental consent
No, they must be 18 or older
explanation: Page 9 clearly states that eligible populations for Supportive Housing services include individuals who are 16 or older. No exceptions are mentioned for younger individuals.

title: Late Assessment Submission
scenario: A provider completes an eligibility assessment on March 1st but doesn't submit it to Wellpoint until March 15th due to staff illness. Wellpoint receives the assessment on March 16th.
question: Will Wellpoint accept this assessment?
options: Yes, assessments are valid for 30 days
No, the assessment is more than 10 business days old
Yes, if the provider provides documentation of the illness
No, assessments must be submitted within 5 days
explanation: Page 22 states that the assessment may not be more than 10 business days old when submitted to Wellpoint. March 1st to March 16th exceeds this limit.

title: Pre-Authorization Services
scenario: An enrollee in crisis needs immediate CSS services. The provider begins providing services on Monday while waiting for Wellpoint's authorization, which arrives Wednesday.
question: Can the provider bill for Monday and Tuesday's services?
options: Yes, crisis situations allow retroactive billing
No, CSS may not be provided or billed prior to authorization
Yes, with proper documentation
No, unless approved by supervisor
explanation: Page 12 explicitly states that CSS may not be provided or billed prior to an authorization for service, with no exceptions mentioned.

title: Service Limit Exception
scenario: An enrollee has used 28 of their 30 authorized CSS days with 60 days remaining in their authorization period. They need continued intensive support due to a housing crisis.
question: What should the provider do to continue services?
options: Continue services and bill after the period ends
Submit an Exception to Rule (ETR) request with supporting documentation
Wait until the next authorization period
Transfer the enrollee to another provider
explanation: Page 23 explains that providers can submit an ETR Form with a signed Single Case Agreement Form and supporting documentation for additional units when clinically necessary.

title: Critical Incident Reporting Delay
scenario: On Friday afternoon, a provider learns that an enrollee was hospitalized Thursday evening due to a mental health crisis. The provider reports the incident to Wellpoint on Monday morning.
question: Did the provider meet reporting requirements?
options: Yes, they reported within 72 hours
No, they should have reported on the same business day they became aware
Yes, weekends don't count for reporting
No, they should have reported within 24 hours
explanation: Page 6 states that critical incidents must be reported to Wellpoint on the same business day of occurrence or provider awareness. The provider became aware Friday and should have reported that day.

title: Overpayment Discovery
scenario: During an internal audit, a provider discovers they accidentally billed for 35 days of CSS services instead of 30 days for an enrollee three months ago. They received $560 in overpayment.
question: What is the provider's obligation?
options: Report and return the overpayment within 60 calendar days of discovery
Wait for Wellpoint to discover the error
Keep the overpayment if not discovered within 90 days
Report it at the annual audit
explanation: Page 54 states that providers must return overpayments within sixty (60) calendar days after the date on which the overpayment was identified.

title: Institutional Contact Frequency
scenario: An individual had one psychiatric hospitalization 11 months ago that lasted 45 days, and no other institutional contacts. They have significant mental health needs.
question: Do they meet the risk factor criteria for CSS based on institutional contacts?
options: Yes, one lengthy stay qualifies
No, they need frequent (2+) or lengthy (90+ days) stays
Yes, any psychiatric hospitalization qualifies
No, it must be within the last 6 months
explanation: Page 9 defines frequent as 2+ contacts in 12 months and lengthy as 90+ consecutive days. One 45-day stay doesn't meet either criterion.

title: Progress Note Requirements
scenario: A provider writes: 'Met with client. Discussed housing. Client doing well. Plan to meet next week.' They include the date but no times.
question: What critical documentation element is missing?
options: Enrollee's response to interventions
Exact start and end times
SMART goals
All of the above
explanation: Page 63-64 requires exact start and end times (not rounded), detailed interventions, enrollee responses, and connection to specific goals in the care plan.

title: Inactive Enrollee Disenrollment
scenario: A provider has tried to contact an enrollee 3 times over 4 weeks using phone calls and one home visit. The enrollee hasn't responded to any attempts.
question: Can the provider initiate involuntary disenrollment?
options: Yes, 3 attempts is sufficient
No, they need at least 4 attempts over 6+ weeks
Yes, if they document the attempts
No, only Wellpoint can disenroll
explanation: Page 24 requires at least four attempts over a minimum of six weeks, with each attempt at least one week apart.

title: Clean Claim Denial
scenario: A provider submits a clean claim on January 15th. By March 20th, they haven't received payment or denial. The claim was complete and accurate when submitted.
question: What is the provider entitled to?
options: Automatic approval of the claim
Interest on the payment if approved
Double payment
Priority processing
explanation: Page 52 states that if Wellpoint doesn't pay the claim within 61 calendar days, they will pay all applicable interest as required by law.

title: Wait Time Violation
scenario: An enrollee arrives for their 2:00 PM appointment. Due to provider delays, they aren't seen until 3:15 PM. The provider didn't notify the enrollee of the delay.
question: What should the provider have done?
options: Seen the enrollee within 30 minutes
Notified the enrollee immediately and offered a new appointment
Provided a discount for the wait
Apologized when they saw the enrollee
explanation: Page 28 states that wait times shouldn't exceed 45 minutes, enrollees should be notified immediately of delays, and offered a new appointment if wait exceeds 45 minutes.

title: TAP Funding Request
scenario: A CSS enrollee needs $6,000 for first month's rent, last month's rent, and security deposit to move into an apartment. The monthly rent is $1,800.
question: Can this be approved through standard TAP funding?
options: Yes, it's for move-in assistance
No, it exceeds the $5,000 limit and needs an ETP
Yes, if split into multiple requests
No, TAP doesn't cover rent
explanation: Page 67 states move-in assistance is limited to $5,000 total. Amounts above this require an Exception to Policy (ETP) request.

title: Employment Service Age Requirement
scenario: A 17-year-old with autism spectrum disorder wants to enroll in supported employment services. They receive SSI benefits and meet all other IPS criteria.
question: Are they eligible for IPS services?
options: No, they must be 18 for employment services
Yes, they meet the minimum age of 16
No, they need work history first
Yes, but only with parental consent
explanation: Page 14 states that individuals must be at least 16 years of age for IPS eligibility. At 17, they meet this requirement.

title: Treatment Record Access
scenario: An enrollee requests copies of their treatment record three times in one year - in January, June, and October. The provider charges $25 for the third copy.
question: Is this charge appropriate?
options: Yes, only one free copy per year is required
No, all copies must be free
Yes, but only $10 can be charged
No, unless pre-approved by Wellpoint
explanation: Page 62 states that enrollees are entitled to one copy of their treatment record each year at no cost. Additional copies may incur charges.

title: Supported Employment Units
scenario: A provider bills for 8 units (2 hours) of H2023 pre-employment services for job coaching provided during a 4-hour shift. The provider was present the entire time.
question: Is this billing appropriate?
options: Yes, partial hours can be billed
No, all 16 units should be billed
Yes, if documented properly
No, only face-to-face time is billable
explanation: Billing should reflect actual services provided. With proper documentation showing 2 hours of actual job coaching during the 4-hour shift, 8 units is appropriate.

title: Fraud Suspicion Reporting
scenario: A provider suspects a colleague is billing for services not provided, based on enrollee complaints and documentation discrepancies. They're unsure whether to report it.
question: What is the provider's obligation?
options: Report only if they have definitive proof
Report suspicions to the SIU hotline at 866-847-8247
Confront the colleague first
Wait for an audit to catch it
explanation: Page 35 provides the SIU fraud referral hotline (866-847-8247) and indicates that suspected fraud should be reported.

title: Enrollment Pause Impact
scenario: During an enrollment pause, an enrollee's 180-day authorization expired 45 days ago. They still need services and meet all eligibility criteria.
question: Can they be reauthorized?
options: Yes, current enrollees can always be reauthorized
No, they missed the 30-day reauthorization window
Yes, with an exception request
No, they must wait for enrollment to reopen
explanation: Page 26 states during enrollment pause, reauthorization must occur within 30 days of expiration. After that, enrollees go on the waitlist.

title: Claim Dispute Timeline
scenario: A provider receives a claim denial on March 1st. They disagree with the denial but don't file a reconsideration request until May 15th, citing staff turnover as the reason for delay.
question: Will the reconsideration be processed?
options: Yes, staff turnover is good cause
No, it exceeds the 24-month deadline
Yes, within 24 months from EOP date
No, without proof of good cause
explanation: Page 58 states reconsideration requests are accepted within 24 months from the date on the EOP. This is well within that timeframe.

title: Multiple Service Billing
scenario: An enrollee receives both CSS (H0043) services in the morning and IPS pre-employment (H2023) services in the afternoon on the same day from the same provider.
question: Can the provider bill for both services on the same day?
options: No, only one FCS service per day
Yes, if properly documented and authorized
No, different providers must deliver each service
Yes, but at a reduced rate
explanation: With proper authorization for both services and appropriate documentation, providers can bill for different FCS services on the same day.
